Article.ArticleTitle: Molecular cloning, characterization and expression analysis of CXCR3a and CXCR3b from Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus).

Abstract.AbstractText: The CXC chemokine receptors (CXCRs) are members of the seven transmembrane (7-TM) G protein-coupled receptor superfamily that involve in innate and adaptive immune systems. In this study, CXCR3a and CXCR3b from Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) were cloned and identified, which designated as OnCXCR3a and OnCXCR3b. The open reading frames of OnCXCR3a and OnCXCR3b were 1074 and 1080 base pairs, encoding the predicted proteins of 357 and 359 amino acids, respectively. Multiple alignment analysis of OnCXCR3a and OnCXCR3b deduced protein sequences with the mammalian and bird sequences indicated that the presence of typical structural features of chemokine receptors, including a 7-TM domain and conserved motifs. Quantitative real-time PCR analysis revealed that OnCXCR3a and OnCXCR3b were constitutively expressed in a wide range of tissues. When stimulated with Streptococcus agalactiae, Aeromonas hydrophila, Poly(I:C) and LPS in vivo, or in vitro on leukocytes, the mRNA levels of OnCXCR3a and OnCXCR3b were significantly up-regulated. Overall, these results indicated that OnCXCR3s might get involved in host immune responses in Nile tilapia.
